text: There's a great book on this, <https://www.amazon.com/Constraint-Theory-Multidimensional-Mathematical-International/dp/3319854836|Constraint Theory by Friedman and Phan>. It starts with a description of how much of a graph someone can fit in their head and reason about, then describes how to make a graph out of your models, then how you can develop some intuition of what to look for, and finally ends with how to automate these to much larger graphs semi-efficiently

elements.text: There's a great book on this,
Constraint Theory by Friedman and Phan

. It starts with a description of how much of a graph someone can fit in their head and reason about, then describes how to make a graph out of your models, then how you can develop some intuition of what to look for, and finally ends with how to automate these to much larger graphs semi-efficiently

text: However, their technique was designed for aerospace engineering, so generally it focuses on feasibility (detecting over/exact constraint) and what questions we can ask the data ("is x vs y with z held constant meaningful/possible?") rather than an executable single output

elements.text: However, their technique was designed for aerospace engineering, so generally it focuses on feasibility (detecting over/exact constraint) and what questions we can ask the data ("is x vs y with z held constant meaningful/possible?") rather than an executable single output
